demographics.name: John Doe
demographics.supportServices: Inpatient admission, physical therapy consult placed.
demographics.mobility: Impaired; requires assistance for transfers due to lower extremity weakness.

diagnosis.primary: Malignant Spinal Cord Compression at T10-T11
diagnosis.likelyPrimary: Poorly differentiated carcinoma of the lung (pending confirmation)
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Progressive lower extremity weakness, back pain, and difficulty walking.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: History of poorly differentiated carcinoma of the lung (presumed).

medications: Dexamethasone 10 mg IV bolus followed by 4 mg PO Q6H

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine in Vac-Lok bag as tolerated due to pain. Arms at side. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: 3-point tattoos at isocenter projections (AP and bilateral laterals).
ctSimulation.ctNotes: Emergent CT simulation performed for rapid 3D-CRT planning. Fused with diagnostic MRI.

fractions.setupNotes: Patient transferred carefully to table. Setup verified with MV imaging.
fractions.sideEffects: No acute side effects from RT. Neurologic status stable post-steroids and first treatment.
fractions.notes: First fraction delivered emergently on the evening of simulation.

imagingAndReports.summary: Confirmed spinal cord compression at T10-T11.

reportDetails.findings: Significant spinal cord compression is noted at the T10-T11 level due to metastatic disease involving the vertebral bodies and epidural space.

imagingAndReports.summary: To confirm primary lung cancer and staging.

progressNotes.author: ED Physician
progressNotes.summary: Patient presented to ED with neurological deficits. MRI confirmed MSCC. Started on high-dose steroids. Radiation oncology consultation initiated emergently.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Robert Green
progressNotes.summary: Radiation therapy simulation completed and first fraction delivered on an emergent basis to decompress the spinal cord.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: Emergency palliative radiation to relieve pressure on the spinal cord, with the goals of preventing permanent paralysis, restoring neurologic function, and relieving pain.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Acute: Fatigue, potential for temporary worsening of pain ('pain flare'), low risk of nausea or skin reaction. Importance of steroid side effects (high blood sugar, insomnia, mood changes) was also reviewed.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: Log-rolling and careful transfers to protect the spine. Immediately report any worsening of weakness, numbness, or loss of bowel/bladder control.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Remain as still as possible during treatment, report all symptoms.
patientEducation.medicationCompliance: Strict adherence to the steroid regimen is critical.

cptCharges.description: Radiation treatment delivery, >1 MeV; 2 separate treatment areas
